What an honor to be sworn in this week surrounded by my family. I will never forget the people who sent me here.
Looking forward to serving on the House Committee on Financial Services. Together we will work to roll back restrictive regulations that strangle job creation.
I’m blessed to have shared this important week with family and friends. #115Congress
Proud to have voted to protect and strengthen our important friendship with #Israel.
Thank you to all the brave men and women who put their lives on the line to keep our communities safe! #LawEnforcementAppreciationDay
Roy Cooper hasn't even been in office a month and is already trying to expand Obamacare. Share this post if you think it's time for repeal.
Having a lot of fun calling folks who won tickets to the Inauguration. Only 10 days away!
I am already fighting for your 2nd Amendment rights. Thank you for the privilege!
ICYMI I gave my first floor speech this week. Check out this quick video to see what else happened!
Today, on #MLKDay, we honor the legacy that Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. left. His vision and commitment for freedom and justice for all will continue to live on.
Enjoyed visiting with everyone at Greensboro's Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial Day Breakfast. Great event!
Always good to be in High Point! #nc13
Great to be with Iredell County's finest. Thanks to Iredell County Sheriff Darren Campbell for coming to the Mooresville stop on the listening tour today.
I’m heading back to Washington with a notebook filled with your concerns and ideas. Looking forward to working to find common-sense solutions to get Washington back to work for you!
Hey everyone -- we ended up with 1 extra ticket to the inauguration.   Share this post for a chance to win it!
Blessed to be able to share this historic moment with our future generation. Thank you for your great drawing!
Humbled to have shared this historic week with so many people from home.
Sending our prayers to Ruth Samuelson's family. Her faith and leadership was an inspiration to all of us.
With a heavy heart, I shared a few words today on the passing of my dear friend Ruth Samuelson.
Great to see that President Trump is keeping his promise to #BuildTheWall. Time to protect our border and keep Americans safe.
Thank you, North Carolina Right To Life for standing up for our most vulnerable.
NA

I applaud POTUS for keeping his promise and choosing a U.S. Supreme Court Justice pick that reflects the views of those who elected him. Judge Neil Gorsuch is a highly qualified pick whose dedication to the Constitution and commitment to protecting individual rights will make him an exceptional Justice once the Senate confirms him.
ICYMI: I cosponsored the #RPMAct to protect North Carolina's stock car legacy from being destroyed by the EPA's threat of over-regulation.
We will kick off our first town hall in a few minutes -- click this link at 2:30pm to listen in! http://bit.ly/2l18Nk6  Can’t wait to hear from you all soon!
Just finished my first Telephone Town Hall. It was great to hear from so many of you back home!   Please keep in touch by signing up for updates here: http://bit.ly/2jCbVqv
It’s encouraging to see President Donald J. Trump taking bold action to roll back restrictive regulations that have killed small businesses and kneecapped local banks.
American taxpayers shouldn't be forced to fund acts of terrorism.
Just a month after getting sworn into office, it was an honor to preside over the United States House of Representatives last night.
I'm honored to work with Congresswoman Alma S. Adams to introduce a resolution that recognizes the significance the Greensboro Four had on North Carolina’s history. http://bit.ly/2k83A9o
I’m fighting to ensure that a veteran-owned small business in my home state isn't getting shut out of competition because of government favoritism towards giant contractors.
Heading back to North Carolina! Watch here to find out what I’ll be up to during my time back home.
Happy #PresidentsDay!
Thank you to International Civil Rights Center & Museum for sharing such a remarkable story with us today.

A North Carolina small business was not allowed to compete for a defense contract made on the last full day of the Obama Administration. I am asking for a Congressional Investigation and will keep working to shed light on this bad deal.  Please help me by sharing this post.   http://www.breitbart.com/big-government/2017/02/21/exclusive-lawmakers-to-request-probe-of-418m-arms-sale-to-kenya-on-obamas-last-day/

Healthcare is an important economic driver in our area. Thank you to Iredell Health System and Wake Forest Innovation Quarter for taking the time to discuss with me the innovations and plans for our future healthcare.

Main street needs rebuilding and everyday families need a chance to succeed.   I’ve heard from many of you about the pains that over regulation has caused in your everyday life. Many of you have shared stories about the struggle to obtain credit for things like car loans or house mortgages.   A few of you have even shared how the Dodd-Frank Act has caused your small business to close up shop.  If you have a story to share about how over regulation has affected your life, please let me know about it here: https://budd.house.gov/fsc-form   Your stories will help in the fight to rebuild our main streets and provide American families with a better future.
Thank you to the Lexington Area Chamber of Commerce for the opportunity to join y’all last night!
It’s not the government's job to pick winners and losers. I’m proud to lead the fight for an investigation into a defense contract that didn’t let a veteran owned NC business compete.

This week I was home listening to health officials, touring hospitals and hearing from constituents about North Carolina’s health care. During the trip, I heard the many ways North Carolina’s medical officials are taking innovative and creative steps to ensure our health care keeps the patient in the picture.

Years of overregulation has discouraged many small businesses to succeed due to over-complication and unnecessary regulation. I want to hear from you if in the past few years you have found it harder to make everyday payments.
Great to welcome veterans from Greensboro to the Capitol today.

Amy Kate has one of the toughest jobs in America, being a homeschool mom to three children, and she does it every day with patience, grace, and love. I am lucky to have her in my life and I am proud that she will be joining me in the House Chamber tonight. #JointAddress
Giant defense contractor caught red handed.
This seems to be just the tip of the iceberg of a real procurement problem.
It's hard for me to think of how this could get more unfair, short of putting a billboard in front of the Pentagon that says "No Small Businesses Need Apply."
Great having the seniors from Hayworth Christian School visit this week!
Great news for American workers and businesses. New #jobsreport shows 230,000+ new jobs added.
Federal Government closed this morning - I'm using the time to talk to constituents back in North Carolina.
Thank you to Gerald Miller and his family from Davidson, NC for coming to my office to pray for me and our country.
Presiding over the US House tonight. Honored to represent North Carolina.
Happy St. Patrick's Day. Wishing everyone celebrating across #NC13 a happy and safe day.
Read my statement on the American Health Care Act.
Late night in Congress, so I took 7th graders from Ellis Middle School on a Capitol Tour. Puts everything we are doing in perspective.
Thank you to all the men and women who have gone beyond the call of duty. May God continue to bless those who have served and are serving. #MedalOfHonorDay
Thank you to the owner of Cheerwine‏ and other bottlers for stopping by this afternoon.
WATCH: I spoke on the floor addressing the need to shine light on the Foreign Military Sale of 12 weaponized border patrol aircraft from the U.S. to the Kenyan Government.
The deadline to submit your artwork to the Congressional Art Competition is approaching fast!
Read my op-ed in the Winston-Salem Journal | JournalNow on why I opposed the American Health Care Act. I look forward to hearing your thoughts.

Tonight, my District Director Todd Poole was in Lexington representing me in honoring Richard Childress, a North Carolina legend and NASCAR Hall of Fame member. Todd presented Mr. Childress with a copy of remarks that I had entered into the Congressional Record.

In today's House Committee on Financial Services hearing, we had a hearing on additional sanctions to Iran.  As some may remember, the last administration brokered a deal with Iran that would get rid of many sanctions in exchange for a pause on the Iranian nuclear program.  Like many, I had concerns about our country signing something that would give permanent sanctions relief in exchange for a temporary pause of nuclear activity.    I’d offer that the signal that sends to neighbors in the region is that they have ten years to get their own nuclear weapons before the Iranians get a nuclear weapon.  It would be very bad news indeed for our national security to see a nuclearized Middle East, one of the most unstable parts of the world. In the hearing, I talked a little about how we might reduce the negative impact of the Iran deal by adding new sanctions not covered by the last administration's deal.
High school students, be sure to submit your artwork for the Congressional Art Competition by April 27th!

There were a couple of hearings this week, and I wanted to share a moment from one of them regarding the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.  It’s an agency with a great mission--protecting the consumer from predatory financial companies. I agree with its mission in many aspects, but at the same time people from all walks of life have also let me know that they’re not happy with the way the agency has gone about that mission. Just about every single business that’s worked with them has come away unhappy, and there are many stories of excessive spending and unfair practices surrounding the agency.  My questions focused on a longtime concern of mine, which is that public service is all too often a passport to self-enrichment in the private sector.  It’s how we end up with one of the most regulated financial systems in the world, that is also one of the most unstable in terms of bailouts and panics. Hope you’ll watch and share your thoughts on this.

I congratulate Justice Neil Gorsuch on his confirmation to the Supreme Court. Throughout his tenure as a judge on the 10th Circuit, Gorsuch has proved his dedication and commitment to the Constitution.   Read my full statement here: http://bit.ly/2nmfraq
Please join me and your entire congressional staff this Friday for a Meet & Greet in Greensboro, North Carolina. Coffee and Muffins will be provided!  RSVP TODAY -->  http://bit.ly/2oazwiA
Thank you for the warm welcome from the middle school students at Northview School. I enjoyed answering all your questions this afternoon.
We just finished our 3 hour Meet & Greet in Greensboro! I enjoyed personally meeting over 200 of you today. Thank you for taking the time to come out and share your thoughts with me.
He is risen! Amy Kate and I wish you and your family a blessed and Happy Easter.

The bad news is today is #TaxDay. The good news is the GOP-led Congress is working on a tax code to simplify the 4 million word long tax code. Simplicity would be a major focus in any tax reform effort. I look forward to working on a reform that helps small businesses and the regular taxpayer.

My thoughts and prayers are with the victims and their families affected by this senseless act of violence.  http://www.yourcentralvalley.com/news/suspect-in-fresno-shooting-spree-that-killed-3-shouts-allahu-akbar-when-arrested/693838151
Thank you to Cheerwine for a great visit in Salisbury yesterday.
I had a great time touring the Honda Aircraft Company in Greensboro this afternoon. Thank you for the hands-on experience in the Flight Safety simulator.

Thank you to everyone who attended yesterday’s ribbon cutting at our Davie County office. Our office is here to ensure that all residents in the district are getting the answers they need from Washington. Too often, citizens are ignored by bureaucrats in Washington, DC and I have assembled a team in our North Carolina office to ensure that doesn’t happen when you contact us.

Traveling across the district these past two weeks, I got to meet hundreds of constituents as well as visit a number of manufacturing businesses. It was a great opportunity to hear directly from people about their concerns as well as talk to businesses about what we need to do to get jobs back to NC. Here are some pictures from my visits.

The deadline for the Annual Congressional Art Competition is coming up this Thursday. If you know a creative high school student, make sure they don’t miss this opportunity to show off their creativity.

Americans shouldn’t have to jump through hoops to avoid funding political causes they don’t support. Unfortunately, millions of union members across the country are faced with this problem. In order to ensure that these workers are getting the protection they deserve, I’ve introduced a simple piece of legislation that would require an employee’s consent before a labor organization uses their dues for any purpose not directly related to collective bargaining.
Every morning the U.S. House starts off the day by standing and saying the pledge of allegiance.
ICYMI: I was live with FreedomWorks discussing why we need to repeal Dodd-Frank and the harm the Durbin Price Control has caused on the consumer.
Great way to start the day. I enjoyed visiting with the 150 students from Northview School this morning.

Small banks are at the heart of our local economy. For many small business owners, local banks provided them their first shot at success. But the local banks that once assisted in building our communities, are now struggling to stay afloat due to the wave of regulations that Dodd-Frank has caused. Since Dodd-Frank came in community banks have disappeared. When I talk to bankers at home, a common theme seems to be that the fastest growing aspect of their business is the compliance department. For every resource diverted to filling out federal paperwork in the growing backroom, there is one less person working to help grow our economy.   Today, the House Committee on Financial Services begins the markup of the Financial #CHOICEAct. I am looking forward to working on creating a scenario where community banks and the small businesses they serve can have the flexibility that they need to grow the economy.
North Carolina’s small businesses are key to growing our local economy. During #smallbusinessweek join me in celebrating the small businesses in our community and the thousands of jobs they support.

Today was not a good day for taxpayers. The omnibus government spending bill that I voted against didn’t reduce spending, did not fund the president's border wall, and fully funded Planned Parenthood.  We have to start advancing the football on our conservative priorities. Today’s omnibus bill did not do that.
On #NationalDayofPrayer I hope you will join me in praying for our country. May God continue to bless our great nation.
We made a quick stop during our district tour to enjoy some of Randy's BBQ in Troutman. I had a great time visiting with folks.

During my visit throughout the district today, I had the opportunity to meet with the Mooresville firefighters, the Iredell county sheriff and deputies, and the ‪Guilford county ‬EMS crew. I want to thank them all again for their hard work and sacrifices they make everyday to keep #NC13 safe.
Thank you to City of Greensboro Fire Department for a great tour of your station and training facility.
Happy #MothersDay to my beautiful wife Amy Kate and to my mom Sylvia. Thanks to all the moms for everything you do!

With over a dozen impressive art submissions from high school students throughout the district, we are excited to announce our 2017 Congressional Art Competition Winner. The selected artwork of colorful umbrellas above a Jerusalem street will hang next to hundreds of other submissions in the hallway of the U.S. Capitol. We are very thankful to everyone who participated in sharing their creativity with us this year.

During this week’s National Police Week, please join me in honoring the men and women who put their lives on the line to protect our families and our communities. We are grateful for their service each and every day. #NationalPoliceWeek

North Carolina’s cherry flavored soda has played an iconic role in our state’s southern way of life. This week, I introduced a resolution that will recognize the significance of Cheerwine’s 100th anniversary.
Gaveling out the US House of Representatives for the week -- always an honor to represent North Carolina.
Grateful to join everyone at today's celebration. Glad I was able to share the official resolution I introduced recognizing Cheerwine's contribution to our great state!

This week we are encouraging you to participate in the People's Choice award. This award provides an opportunity for you to choose the 2nd place winner for the 2017 Congressional Art Competition.  To cast your vote to choose the 2nd place winner "like" the artwork you would like to nominate as the “People’s Choice” winner.   The photo with the most "likes" will be this year's winner. The winning submission will be on display in our district office.   The deadline for the competition will be Thursday, May 25th, 2017 at 5:00 pm.
Praying for the victims and families of this act of terror in Manchester. We stand united with our allies.
During #EMSweek join me in thanking all the EMS crews who work across our state and our country to keep our communities safe when disastrous situations occur.
Congratulations to our People’s Choice winner, Alexis Elliot from Statesville Christian School. Thank you to everyone who participated in this year’s 2017 Congressional Art Competition.

This Memorial Day weekend we honor the men and women who guarded our way of life with their very lives. It is because of these sacrifices that ensure that liberty is passed on to our next generation. These fallen heroes have our unending gratitude. Thank you.

I spent this Memorial Day aboard the USS Ronald Reagan thanking the sailors who are protecting us in the Asia-Pacific region. Thank you to all who have served and are away from their families. Today we especially honor those who have paid the ultimate sacrifice.
Watch a short message honoring our fallen heroes this Memorial Day.

Right now a foreign company is working to use legal gymnastics in order to hurt a U.S. company that employs more than 150 people in Greensboro, North Carolina.    This week, I sent a letter with a group of North Carolina lawmakers  underlining  to the International Trade Commission (ITC) that if they rule in favor of the foreign company, it would have a major negative impact on jobs in our district.

During my time overseas this week, I went aboard the nuclear-powered aircraft carrier USS Ronald Reagan and saw first hand our brave sailors at work.  I also met with military leaders in the Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) in Korea.  As one of the countries that our president has called the “greatest immediate threat” to the U.S., I took the opportunity to gain first-hand knowledge of the different threats North Korea brings to our country and our allies.
My thoughts and prayers are with the victims of last night’s #LondonAttacks. We stand united with our allies.
Congratulations to the North Davidson High School softball team on winning this year's 4A State Softball Championship! Such an inspiring story of strength and dedication.

The anniversary of #DDay marks the momentous occasion when thousands of American soldiers stormed the beaches of Normandy, France on June 6, 1944. We will forever remember and honor the valor and sacrifice that was demonstrated 73 years ago.

The more complicated the system, the more likely it is to break down. Dodd-Frank is nothing if not complex, adding 400 new rules and 2,300 pages of new regulations onto the financial system.   The Financial #ChoiceAct replaces this complexity and weakness with simplicity and strength. Under Choice, banks that, in essence, keep significant cash on hand as a shock absorber against economic bumps in the road, get out from under Dodd-Frank’s web of red tape.    Families and small business owners know that there’s no substitute for savings during tough economic times. The principle behind the Financial Choice Act is to put a similar standard on banks.
I want to hear from you on a number of different issues. Please fill out our online survey today.
Congratulations to Davidson County Schools, NC High School senior Austin Beck for being picked 6th for the MLB Draft.
Amy Kate and I are sending our prayers to Rep. Steve Scalise and everyone who was injured this morning. Thank you, Capitol Police Officers for your service.
In today’s House Committee on Financial Services markup on Flood Insurance, we took a moment to reflect on yesterday's senseless act of violence.
Did you miss our e-newsletter last week? Read it here.
Join me in congratulating The Congressional Award winners. It was great to visit with these incredible young leaders this afternoon. Keep up your hard work and dedication.
Just a few short years after our state was officially founded, the Salisbury Post Office was established. Today, it celebrated its 225th anniversary! Congratulations on an impressive milestone.

A couple of days ago I signed a letter to Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg asking her to withdraw from ruling on the president’s executive order suspending travel from high terrorism risk countries.    Justice Ginsburg is a public servant of long standing, but she has made sharply critical comments about the president, calling into question her ability to rule impartially.    Whatever you may think about President Trump, 63 million people voted for him, and if his policies are going to be struck down as unconstitutional, it should be because of the law, not because of a judge's political beliefs.     http://www.salisburypost.com/2017/06/27/reps-budd-hudson-ask-supreme-court-justice-recuse-travel-ban-case/

Earlier today, I introduced a bill with Rep. Kyrsten Sinema (D-AZ), that would direct the Secretary of the Treasury to develop a national strategy to combat terrorism financing.  This legislation gets at the idea that we need an all-of-the-above strategy to combat international terrorism.  Too often this is looked at from a perspective of military intervention vs. diplomacy, but what this bill speaks to is the fact that there’s a number ways we can address the problem.  Availability of funding, along with radical Islamist ideologies, are among the roots of terrorism.  It’s worth remembering that Al Capone was arrested and jailed not because of violent acts he had committed, but because he was evading federal taxes.  It’s my hope that the national strategy our bill calls for has a similar degree of success.  My statement on the bill is below...  https://budd.house.gov/media/press-releases/budd-sinema-introduce-legislation-combat-terrorist-financing-0

There were a couple of bills the House voted on yesterday that I thought were worth sharing a little bit about.  Kate’s law, a bill that would toughen penalties for those who come here illegally, commit crimes, and then re-enter the country, passed the House with bipartisan support, 257-167.  The No Sanctuary for Criminals Act, a bill that would cut funding to cities that ignore federal immigration laws, passed the House 228-195. I voted yes on both, and I thought it was worth talking about why.     The Constitution says that Congress has the power “to establish a uniform rule of Naturalization.”  It’s one of the few powers that are explicitly given to the federal government, based on the notion that immigration and borders are a national issue.  Congress has done so a number of times, most recently in 1996 when then-President Clinton signed the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act into law.     If every state or city could ignore those laws, then whichever city or state with the loosest laws would set policy for everyone else.  What struck me about the sanctuary cities bill was that it was an attempt to get us back towards an immigration policy that is truly national in nature.  There are potentially tragic consequences for having an uneven approach on this front.     The circumstances of Kate Steinle’s death, the young woman for whom the other bill was named, adds urgency to this goal.  Kate Steinle was walking with her father in San Francisco when she was shot to death by an illegal alien who had been deported five times.  The federal government had issued a detention order for her murderer, but because San Francisco is a sanctuary city, Kate Steinle’s murderer was not deported before he had a chance to commit his crime.       The bill that was named for her would toughen penalties for those who come into our country, are deported for committing felonies, and then come back again.  I’d offer that trying to deter serious criminals from coming back into our country after deportation was a relatively commonsense notion--so much so that the bill got significant support from both sides of the aisle.    The video below from the Judiciary Committee has more.
This Fourth of July, please join me in celebrating the freedoms and liberties that our forefathers established. Happy #FourthofJuly

Praying for the families and loved ones of the 15 Marines and 1 Sailor we lost in yesterday’s plane crash in Mississippi en route from Cherry Point, NC. Amy Kate and I are sending our condolences to everyone who is touched by the devastating tragedy.

Earlier this week I joined with Congresswoman Kyrsten Sinema (D-AZ) and Congressman Brian Fitzpatrick (R-PA) to offer an amendment to the yearly defense bill that ensured that our country’s strategy to counter ISIS in Syria included a focus on disrupting the financing networks that make terrorism possible.  Given that I’ve introduced a bill on that front to create a unified national strategy across the federal government, it struck me as reasonable to ensure that was one component of our country’s foreign policy activities in Syria.    The amendment was approved by the House, and will become part of the final bill that is going to the Senate.  After both houses pass the defense bill, there will likely be a conference committee where the House and Senate will iron out some of the differences between the bills before they send the final product over to the president for his signature.  Since the overall bill has this reform in it as well as many others, I’m hoping that we’ll see speedy action on it going forward.

The House is running out of time. We have four big-ticket items on the Republican agenda: Obamacare repeal, tax reform, the president’s infrastructure bill, and funding the president’s border wall. None of these bills have been signed into law.   It’s no wonder the American people flat out hate Congress - we’re taking too much time off. That’s why I am committed to staying through August Recess to tackle at least one of these many big ticket items. Read my op-ed to learn more.

One of the responsibilities of the United States Congress is overseeing defense budget since 1776.  This year the House will engage two separate times on legislation dealing with our military’s spending. The first time we will establish and authorize the budget, and the second time we will enable military departments and agencies to use the funds from the United States Treasury.  One bill will create the plan, and the other will fund the plan. The bill we voted on today is the plan bill--the funding bill will come later this year.     The House passing of 2018 National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) upholds our commitment to the Constitution as Congress continues to reform the way the Department of Defense operates. The 2018 NDAA will begin rebuilding our military by increasing the size of our departments as well as enhancing our defenses by modernizing our strategies and weapons.  Perhaps most importantly, the troops will get a substantial pay raise, the largest in 8 years.    As a part of the improvements to our strategies, I am proud to have worked with both parties to contribute an amendment to the FY18 NDAA.  What it would do is help ensure that our country’s strategy to counter ISIS in Syria includes a focus on disrupting the financing networks that make terrorism possible.
Glad North Carolina's iconic soda company, Cheerwine was invited to participate at The White House's #MadeinAmerica event this afternoon.
I want to hear from you. Do you think Congress should cancel August recess and add some extra work days to our year? Take my survey here →
Amy Kate and I are sending our prayers to Senator John McCain and his loved ones during this difficult time.

Another chapter in the fight to protect the Greensboro jobs supported by the American ATM manufacturer...  Diebold, an ATM manufacturer who employs 120 people in Greensboro, and around 5,000 in our country lost an element of its case in front of the International Trade Commission to a Korean manufacturer.  The next phase is the appeals process, which I'm working on assisting with...more on this below.
I had a great time tonight at the Iredell County Farm Bureau Legislative Appreciation Dinner.
Congratulations to the Rowan Little League softball team on winning the state tournament.

I want to congratulate Lexington and Davidson county for today's huge economic announcement. Our state’s long history with furniture manufacturing and skilled workforce makes the area a great location for Egger Woods Products to invest their company’s future. We are thrilled to celebrate the addition of nearly 800 new jobs for the area.

I fully support efforts for a robust response to attempts by the Russian Federation to interfere with the American election process and their ongoing occupation of Crimea. If a country doesn’t play by the rules, America should respond, and this bill is an important step in that process.

Today, I passed my first bill through the U.S. House of Representatives. My terrorism bill was included in the Russia, Iran, and North Korea Sanctions Act, an effort to use economic sanctions to deter bad behavior by rogue states, including Russia for their state-sponsored hacking of the 2016 presidential election. The bipartisan Budd-Sinema legislation establishes a comprehensive national strategy to combat the financing of terrorism and related forms of illicit finance.  I’m proud of the bipartisan work done on this bill, and I’m particularly grateful to Congresswoman Kyrsten Sinema for her efforts here. The Senate has already passed a similar bill, and I’m looking forward to seeing this legislation on the president’s desk soon.  Read more here: http://bit.ly/2uyMZm0

Let me take a minute to give an update on what’s going on over in the Senate, in regards to health care.   Yesterday afternoon, the Senate voted in favor of proceeding to debate how we should reform our country’s health system. Over the next couple of days, members of the Senate will debate and vote on many amendments aimed to improve our health care system.   The Constitution requires any bill that seeks to make changes to taxes needs to start here in the House, which is why the Senate could not begin this process until the House passed a bill. In early May, we sent the American Health Care Act over to them. Since then, Senators have been engaged in a lengthy debate on how best to reform our healthcare system. With a divided conference, like ours, finding consensus is never easy.   At the end of this process, it’s my hope that the Senate sends us back a product that will lower premiums for people buying on the individual marketplace and repeals the individual mandate, ensuring that Americans aren’t forced to buy health insurance by the federal government against their own will.   I’ll have more thoughts on this as the week progresses. In the meantime, we will be working.
Congrats NASCAR Technical Institute and Roush Yates Engines for partnering up on the premier CNC machine lab in the southeast. Closing the skills gap!
Great visit with Terry Osborne from Rowan county and his guests this morning. Keep up the good work on your award winning underage drinking prevention program.

There’s a great deal of disagreement on how much the government should spend and on what programs.  Where I think there’s more agreement is that, if the government does decide to spend money, it should make sure that taxpayer dollars are used as wisely as possible.    There’s a law called the Davis-Bacon Act that was created during the New Deal to ensure that the federal government did not come into smaller communities and overwhelm the local labor market with low wages.  It requires federal contracts to pay the “prevailing wage.”  How they get to that number is a badly flawed process--sometimes it’s as much as double the market wage, other times it’s minimum wage.  It’s been estimated that Davis-Bacon adds about 10 percent to the cost of federal construction projects.    I joined with Congressman Francis Rooney, a member from Florida, last night to offer an amendment that partially overturns this law, and helps get us to a place where the federal government is getting the best bang for the taxpayer buck when it does decide to spend money.    The video’s below:

This week I introduced a bill called the Reset Act of 2017 that will allow Congress to review every major rule on the books and overturn them if they are not needed.  If my bill goes into law, we will have taken a significant step towards a more accountable and responsive system.

The Senate’s failure to find consensus last night to repeal and replace Obamacare is disappointing, but it does not mean the fight is over. The American people gave the Republican Party full control of Congress on the premise that Obamacare would be repealed and giving up now is not an option. There is more work to be done, but it is work worth doing. Obamacare repeal will remain a top priority for me until this Congress is able to deliver on the promises that have been made to the American people.

It was great to meet with organizers of the annual Game Plan For Life and representatives from the Rowan-Kannapolis Alcoholic Beverage Control Board to discuss their efforts to stop underage drinking in North Carolina. This group’s work has proven that strong leadership and support is important to maintaining a healthy community.
#DidyouKnow, this year Congress increased our defense funding by $21 billion and authorizing additional resources to counter threats, increase end-strength, and enhance our military’s readiness.

I’m grateful for President Donald J. Trump's decision to sign this important legislation, which includes my bill ordering the Secretary of the Treasury to create a national strategy to counter terrorist financing networks. Former President Bush was right when he declared that “money is the lifeblood of terrorist operations.”  My bill represents a significant step towards an effective, sustained national strategy to attack the funding that makes terrorism possible.  It is critical that we continue to maximize cooperation among federal departments to keep our policies ahead of the evolving threat from ISIS, Al-Shabaab, Al-Qaeda, and other terrorist groups.
Congrats to High Point University for being included on the list of the "Best 382 Colleges."
The men and women who served our country should not be victims of a VA system. I’ll continue to support legislation to ensure that veterans in our state have the best possible care.
Happy 227th birthday to the U.S. Coast Guard. Thank you to the men and women of the Coast Guard for your service and dedication to protecting our waterways and coasts!

Congrats to Greensboro, North Carolina for being ranked 3rd on CNN Travel's southern “Charming Cities” list.

It was wonderful to meet with Army Veteran Leora Prude in my district office. Thank you for your service. I am always happy to assist constituents who are trying to resolve problems with a federal government agency. Diebold-Nixdorf is a ATM and safe manufacturer with 150 employees in Greensboro.  A few weeks ago, they lost a trade dispute with Hyosung, a Korean ATM manufacturer with a few dozen employees in the United States.  Previously, Hyosung had copied Diebold’s technology, and itself lost a major case in front of the International Trade Commission. The ruling of a few weeks ago represents an attempt by Hyosung to use the same system for its own advantage.    Diebold has 4,700 jobs in our country, Hyosung has a few dozen.  I’m hopeful that the United States Trade Representative makes the right decision, and overturns this flawed ruling.

Today I voted for the Hurricane Harvey disaster relief bill that will directly fund the recovery efforts in Texas.  I hope that the Senate will act quickly to pass this clean bill so that families in Texas can get the relief they need.  My prayers continue to be with the people of Texas as they deal with the aftermath of this horrible storm.

This week, I introduced an amendment to the transportation funding bill that would eliminate a $900 million earmark to fund a Amtrak bridge tunnel in New Jersey. My reasoning for this amendment is simple… I don’t think it is right for one project to suck up all the funds that were intended for projects throughout the country.   Tonight, I debated my amendment on the House floor to make the case against sending 100 percent of FY 2018 funds to a project that New Jersey cancelled in 2010, because of the high price tag. It isn’t right for North Carolina taxpayers to have to send their hard earned dollars to pay for a tunnel in New Jersey.   This is a big earmark, in fact, it is 300 times the size of the average earmark when they were legal. Billions are about to pour out of Washington.  If this earmark stands, then we send a unfortunate message to states governments: shortchange your infrastructure, and Washington will bail you out.      Watch my speech here: http://bit.ly/2j73UKv

It is estimated that the Palestinian Authority spends 10% of its budget on payouts to the families of dead or captured terrorists.  If you deliberately commit terrorism, your family should not get a bonus, and that bonus should certainly not be paid for with American taxpayer dollars.  Until that happens I’m going to work on pressuring the Palestinian Authority to stop incentivizing terrorism.   Today, my first amendment was adopted by the House as a part of H.R. 3354, the Make America Secure and Prosperous Appropriations Act, 2018. The amendment makes sure that no federal funds will be used to honor or compensate the families of jailed or martyred terrorists in the West Bank and Gaza.   I’m hopeful we’ll see this policy change.
My prayers are with everyone affected by #HurricaneIrma2017. For information on how to stay safe and prepare, please visit  www.ready.gov.

Providing quick relief for victims of Hurricane Harvey was a top priority for me this week, which is why I joined my colleagues on Wednesday to send a bill to the Senate that provided over $7 billion in emergency relief.  I realize that there are millions of Texans who were affected by Hurricane Harvey that need our assistance right now. Unfortunately, the Senate decided to use this as an opportunity to change what was an immediate disaster relief bill into a government funding and debt-ceiling increase bill as well.  The people who have had their way of life washed away from them do not have time for Congress to be attaching irrelevant items to what was a clean disaster relief bill.  Funding our government and ensuring our country doesn’t default on our debt are important tasks that deserve individual debates, which is why I voted today to oppose the Senate’s effort to poison our Harvey relief funding bill.

What do the movie “Top Gun,”  the song “That's What Friends Are For,” the Chicago Bears winning the Super Bowl and our tax code all have in common…  They all happened in the year 1986.   Now in 2017, Congress has a once in generation opportunity to update our tax code and pass a fair, simple and pro-growth tax code. The House Republicans blueprint to reform our tax code aims to create more jobs for Americans and put money back in the pockets of hardworking American families and individuals across America. Earlier today a tax reform framework was released and, after having a chance to dive into it, I’m encouraged by the opportunity we have to reform our system for the first time in over thirty years. While there will always be debate on how the changes should be made, most people agree that an outdated tax code isn’t healthy for our economy.   I want to see three things happen as a result of this bill: leave middle-class families in our State with more money in their pocket next year and in years to come, bring jobs back from overseas and simplify the tax filing process for everyone. The framework released today would do all of those things.   While the framework includes many different provisions, I want to point to two of them that would be a boost to families at home and our country’s economy, at large.   First, this plan would nearly double the standard deduction for both individuals and married couples, meaning that the first $12,000 you earn (and $24,000 for joint filers) is completely tax-free. For many people, the process of itemizing deductions is fairly complex and burdensome, as taxpayers have to track and record relevant expenses throughout the year, and possibly longer. Doubling the standard deduction will allow many more families to avoid itemizing their deductions, saving time, and providing a major tax reduction even for those who do not itemize.    The other part of the released framework that I thought was worth highlighting is that it would bring the corporate tax rate down to 20% from its current rate of 38.9%. We need to attract businesses to stay here, and if they have left, to return. This is something that many countries around the world have already figured out, and was even supported by the last Administration.    It’s a long way from a plan to a bill to a law, but this is an important first step, and I’m going to do what I can to see this plan executed and signed into law.
Welcome back Congressman Steve Scalise!

Major incidents of hacking in the private sector continue to underscore the need for strong data security. Americans are required to turn over a host of financial information to the Treasury Department, and accordingly, we should be doing what we can to make sure that this information is as secure as possible.  Today, I introduced a bill, Treasury Innovation Act, to help secure our financial info from data breaches. This legislation would financially reward those who discover and report issues with the Treasury Department’s servers. Federal computer systems are prime targets for hackers, and harnessing the power of the private sector to find and eliminate vulnerabilities before hackers strike is an important tool in the toolkit for increased data security. My bill is a step in the right direction by helping expose problems and allowing us time to find solutions before the unthinkable happens.
Our prayers are with the family and friends of Coach Mike Lambros and the entire North Davidson community.

It’s hard to find a better example of the left hand not knowing what the right hand is doing than one part of the government paying money to people another part of the government is trying to put in jail. It strikes me as common sense that if we’re going to take money from law abiding taxpayers, we ought not to be giving it to lawbreaking recipients.   This week, I voted in favor of a bill that will help fix this problem by reining in government payments to parole violators.   The CUFF Act would prevent individuals with active arrest warrants and parole violators from receiving Supplemental Security Income payments, saving around $200 million in federal spending a year.  The bill passed the House with a bipartisan majority.
As we learn more about this horrendous act in Las Vegas, my prayers are with the victims and their families.

Today, I spoke on the House floor in support of the Pain-Cable Unborn Child Protection Act, which would end late-term elective abortions after 5 months. I am proud to support this legislation as we take steps toward protecting the unborn.

On September 7, 2017, Equifax Inc. announced that hackers had stolen personal identifying information, including social security numbers, for approximately 143 million U.S. consumers. Beyond basic disclosures provided by Equifax, there is limited additional public information about the breach. Today, the House Financial Services held a hearing to reveal some facts about the causes of the data breach and how it affects consumers.   During the hearing, I questioned former CEO and Chairman of Equifax Richard Smith on the specifics of the decision to allow those responsible for the breach to retire instead of terminating their employment.   I am hopeful that Mr. Smith’s response revealing that those who were responsible did not receive severance packages is accurate, and it’s good that there was some accountability to come out of this terrible event.

One of the most concerning federal decisions in the past five years was Operation Choke Point, a concerted effort by the last administration to drive certain businesses out of the financial system.  These included payday lenders, coal producers, firearms dealers, and a host of other legal industries.  It was an abuse of power, and I’m glad President Trump ended the practice. This Financial Institution Consumer Protection Act would prevent it from happening again.  I spoke a little bit about my experience with the issue.

We’ve the same number of public companies today as we did in the early 1980s, when the economy was much smaller. There’s mounting evidence that we’ve got a problem there. Today the House Committee on Financial Services passed legislation introduced by Representative Gregory Meeks and me last week.  This bill is a step towards making going public more attractive, getting our financial markets back towards being the number one method for capital formation. I’m proud to see this legislation passed unanimously through Committee today.

It has been a busy couple of weeks and I would like to share with you a few things that I have been doing.

Many things have changed in our country since 1986. Back then, “Cheers” was the most popular show on television, the Internet wasn’t around, and the iPhone was unimaginable. We have come a long way since then. Unfortunately, our tax code is stuck in the past.   Read my op-ed in the News & Record on why we need to reform the tax code.

How does a tiny, isolated country like North Korea have the ability to fund and develop a nuclear weapons program with the capability to strike American soil? Today, on the House floor, I addressed this question and explained how a bipartisan bill will help curb the advancement of North Korea’s nuclear weapon’s program.  Watch my speech below.

The opioid epidemic has hit our communities rapidly over the past few years. In our  state we lost more than 12,000 people from 1999 to 2016 of opioid-related overdoses. In 2016, the Obama Administration signed into law a bill that weakened the DEA’s ability to go after corrupt pain clinics that are a major part of opioid epidemic. Stripping the DEA of its authority to block suspicious sales of pills removes a crucial tool to fight back against this deadly epidemic.  This week, I cosponsored Restoring Enforcement Standards to Track Opioids Responsively Act a bill that restores the DEA’s authority to carry out needed enforcement to combat drug diversion and the opioid epidemic.
We must give our law enforcement every possible tool to fight the opioid epidemic and that’s why I co-sponsored this important legislation.

The City of Lexington - Government is a great example of how North Carolina’s business-friendly climate is helping grow our local economies. The most recent business to join our community is Chick-fil-A.

Yesterday, the House passed the 2018 budget and unlocked the opportunity to reform our tax code. The swift passage of the budget shows promise for the American people who are in desperate need of tax relief. The House took a crucial first step towards reforming our country’s tax code -- something we haven’t done in over thirty years. I look forward to working with my colleagues in the coming weeks to pass a bill that will give working-class Americans a raise and simplify the tax filing process for years to come.

The financial markets connect money to ideas and helps develop those ideas into products and services that we all use. Our country has the same number of public companies today as in the 1980s.  There are a number of reasons for that, but one of them is that the process of going public has become more and more difficult.  Today, the house passed the Encouraging Public Offerings Act, a bill which I introduced with Gregory W Meeks earlier this year. The bill will make significant changes to the securities laws to reduce the risk that companies face when they go public, and ensure that the everyday investor has access to the opportunities that help Americans who save see their money grow.

Did you know that veteran-owned businesses make up nearly 10 percent of all United States businesses? This week’s National Veterans Small Business Week join me in sharing our appreciation for these men and women’s continued service to the United States through small business ownership and entrepreneurship.

This is an exciting day. Today marks another important milestone in the process of reforming our tax code for the first time in over thirty years. Since the beginning, I have asked three main questions: will this bill cut taxes for the middle-class, does this bill make our business climate competitive in the global economy, and does this bill simplify the tax filing process for people at home? The answer to all of these questions are ‘yes.’  Specifically, as a result of this bill the average middle-class family in my district earning $59,000 will receive a $1,182 tax cut. Rather than giving it to the IRS, a family would be able to keep this money and use for more important things such as raising their children or paying down debt.   While there are still many steps left before any tax laws are changed, I’m optimistic and look forward to working with my colleagues in the coming weeks to pass much-needed tax relief for the American people before Christmas.

I am pleased to have voted in favor of repealing the Independent Payment Advisory Board. If someone thought bipartisanship in regards to health care was impossible, they were wrong. This week, we saw both Republicans and Democrats come to together in support of the Constitution by restoring the power of policy-making back to Congress.  Obamacare created this board, which is supposed to consist of fifteen unelected bureaucrats with the responsibility of recommending ways to cut Medicare - the program that provides healthcare to millions of seniors around the country.  My view on this is pretty simple. Any changes in Medicare policy should be left to Congress, not fifteen unelected bureaucrats.
My statement on today's heartbreaking news from Sutherland Springs, Texas.

Last week was an important one, as it marked the beginning of the Republican effort to deliver on another promise: tax relief for the middle class. I share the frustration of many at home in the failure of the Senate to repeal Obamacare, but in this chapter there’s an opportunity for redemption for the Republicans, and I’m very hopeful that by Christmas we will be able to pass tax reform that will put more money in your pocket. Today the House passed the 2018 National Defense Authorization Act. This will be the 56th year this legislation has been signed into law. The bill will allow our military to begin necessary rebuilding by increasing the size of different service branches as well as modernizing strategies and weapons.  Perhaps most importantly, the troops will get a substantial pay raise, the largest in eight years.    I’m was heartened to see these important reforms in the bill, and look forward to it heading into law.

Today, the House Financial Services Committee began its consideration of 23 measures. The bills debated in today’s markup would strengthen our economy, provide accountability to the Federal Reserve, and protect our financial system by holding the Iran regime accountable for its illicit activities. While all these bills help make a difference for Americans, there is one that I spoke in favor of earlier today: HR 4324, the Strengthening Oversight of Iran’s Access to Finance Act.  The Iran regime continue to find new and creative ways to bypass sanctions to fund their worldwide terror network.  Lifting sanctions on Iran not only opens the United States up to potentially financing Iran’s destabilizing activity and terror program in the region, it also creates potential money laundering risks for American financial institutions.   It is my hope that the bill will serve as an effective counterweight to Iranian destabilization efforts in the region.   Overall, I look forward to seeing the bills move to the floor and will continue to keep you updated on their progress as the markup continues tomorrow.

Over the last few decades, Congress has cut some taxes here and there, but we’re overdue for meaningful reform. Hardworking taxpayers in North Carolina are right to ask why it’s been so long since we’ve reformed our tax code. The unfortunate truth is that for many years Congress has thrown up the white flag in defeat against K Street lobbyists and settled for preserving the status quo.  Watch my floor speech from last night to find out how the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act would be a win for manufactures, savers and hardworking families.

For over 30 years hardworking American families have been forced to put up with a broken tax code that puts special interest groups first. For too long Congress has thrown up the white flag in defeat against lobbyists and settled for preserving the status quo.   We took a major step in changing that today by passing a bill that would get rid of lobbyist loopholes and give working families a tax cut that they have long deserved. Instead of the IRS taking their money, these families will now be able to use this money on their children or for paying down their debts.   I am proud to have played a small part in finally delivering a tax bill that will make America more competitive and puts money back in the pockets of hardworking taxpayers.

This week, the House Committee on Financial Services  approved 23 bills. In total, the committee has approved 63 bills, since my first day serving on Financial Service back in January. Overall, the bills passed this week are aimed at getting our economy working by providing accountability and transparency in the financial system. Of these bills, there are two that I would like to highlight: Restoring Financial Market Freedom Act of 2017, HR 4247 and HR 4293, Stress Test Improvement Act.  The first one is a bill that I introduced, the Restoring Financial Market Freedom Act of 2017, HR 4247. This legislation addresses Title VIII of Dodd-Frank, which creates another category of too big to fail financial firms and gives them an explicit government backstop.  My bill would reverse that decision, and it was reported out of Committee by a majority vote.    The final bill that I would like to highlight this evening is HR 4293, Stress Test Improvement Act. What this one comes down to is the idea that to follow the law, it’s fair that people have an idea what exactly the law is.  Right now, banks get tested by their regulators for soundness.  In order to avoid letting banks game their tests, the Federal Reserve keeps the criteria secret.  It’s a little bit like going into an exam at school where the teacher doesn’t tell anyone what the exam is actually going to test.    This bill gets at is the notion that stress testing is a useful exercise, but it should be a transparent, regular, and predictable exercise. Overall, I look forward to seeing the bills move to the floor.

Congress has been busy keeping our promise of passing legislation that puts working families first and keeping our country safe. Yesterday, North Korea tested an intercontinental ballistic missile for the first time since July of this year.  The Pentagon has confirmed that the missile traveled 600 miles, a significant improvement over previous tests.  What this underscores is just how important it is we continue to maintain our military, and to continue to attack sources of financing and money laundering that North Korea uses to fund its technology.  It is only a matter of time before North Korea acquires the ability to launch an attack on the entire United States unless we are able to stop their pursuit of this capability.    Ultimately, looking at the issue from the short-term from a congressional perspective, demands that immigration amnesty be included funding bills at the end of this year have the potential to disrupt the operations of our military by leading to a shutdown.  I think the situation in North Korea makes it all the more vital that we head off those efforts and provide some stability for our efforts to stop North Korea’s escalating threat.

I wanted to write a little on the current issue with the leadership of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, an agency tasked with enforcing financial regulation on banks, credit unions, and other businesses.  Basically, the facts of the case are that after Richard Cordray, the current leader of the agency, resigned his position, President Trump appointed Mick Mulvaney to serve in his place.  Cordray appointed his own successor, Leandra English, leaving two people with the same title vying for control of the bureau.    The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is a controversial agency, and I voted for a bill that would replace the single director with a bipartisan commission, in line with other independent agencies of the federal government, such as the Federal Trade Commission or the Securities Exchange Commission.  Others in Congress, particularly those who are more left-leaning, resisted doing so.  I voted as I did because I had concerns about vesting so much power in the hands of a single unelected individual--in particular someone that isn’t part of our three-branch system.      Now we have something of a crisis. Even though the federal courts have ruled that Trump’s choice has control of the agency, there is a long appeals process ahead.  In the meantime, what happens if Mulvaney says one thing, and English says another?  Who are banks and credit unions supposed to listen to?    Ultimately, my hope is this mini-crisis isn’t a sign of greater constitutional issues to come.  It’s important that even in times like these, where emotions are running high in the political process, that we respect the powers laid down in the Constitution.

Today, I spoke on the House floor regarding last week’s horrific terrorist attack in Egypt. What made this tragedy even worse is that it happened at a place of worship in a mosque in the northern Sinai region. President Trump was right to say after the attack in Egypt that we should strengthen our efforts to defeat terrorism and extremism in all of its forms.
North Carolina makes Forbes’ “Best States for Business” for the twelfth straight year.

Last week I signed on as a cosponsor to the Every Prescription Conveyed Securely (EPCS) Act. This is part of my ongoing effort to address our country’s opioid epidemic.   One of the problems we face with the epidemic is there isn’t a nationwide system in place to track a patient’s prescription history. One consequence from this is that it allows for dealers and addicts to get away with using fraudulent paper prescriptions. According to the Centers for Disease Control, 27 percent of those at the highest risk of overdose are prescribed painkillers by more than 1 physician. The bill aims to eliminate duplicative prescriptions  This bill would require all prescribers to to use an electronic health record, which allows states to monitor and track the use of opioids. While this surely isn’t the only action that needs to be taken, eliminating duplicative prescriptions would be a huge step in combatting this epidemic.   I will be sure to keep you updated on my efforts to combat the opioid epidemic in the coming weeks and months.
Thank you, N.C. Farm Bureau  for having me today at the NCFB Annual Meeting in Greensboro City

Congress continues to show momentum as we head into our final month of the year. I am optimistic that Congress will pass a tax reform bill that puts more money back in the pockets of hard working Americans. In addition to the momentum behind tax reform, I would like to share a few more items that occurred last week.

I applaud President Trump for fulfilling his promise to recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. Today’s announcement sends a clear signal to the world that in any coming peace negotiations we will not be pressuring Israel to give up its historic and religious capital.   Congress passed a bipartisan law back in 1995 that required the movement of our embassy from Tel-Aviv to Jerusalem. This same law also stated that Jerusalem should be the “undivided” capital of Israel.  This historic move by President Trump shows, once again, that the bond between our two countries is stronger than ever.

I applaud the passage of the Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act today. As things stand, each state currently determines its own concealed carry laws. And some states don’t recognize concealed carry permits from other states. This puts lawful gun owners at risk when travelling. The current system has created accidental criminals, ruined lives, and punished gun owners simply because they fell victim to complexity and uncertainty in the law.  The Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act would, if it went into law, address this problem by bringing much needed clarity to the system. H.R. 38 is a simple proposal, but a necessary one, and if enacted it will allow lawful owners to carry their firearm into other states that allow concealed carry. This interstate recognition of concealed carry would be similar to a driver’s license.  The Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act is common sense legislation that will bring clarity to this complex system.
Seventy-six years ago, America woke up to a day which would live in infamy. Please join me in remembering and honoring the courageous men and women who lost their lives at #PearlHarbor.
Any country where the Kate Steinle tragedy can happen is not a country with a sane immigration policy.  Kate Steinle proves that we are not there yet.  But I believe we could get there one day.

Snow is starting to fall at our Davie County office. Be careful out there!

Congress had a busy week, and I want to share a few quick bullet points of some of the events that happened.   - President Trump made a historic decision to recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel.   - Congress passed The Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act, a bill that will expand gun owners’ rights and preserve our 2nd Amendment.   - Avoided a government shutdown by passing a two-week spending bill.  - Passed Venezuela Humanitarian Assistance and Defense of Democratic Governance Act of 2017, a bill to aid the Venezuelan people during their current humanitarian crisis and enforce sanctions to stop corrupt government officials from profiting on people's misery.   - Finally, we voted to go to conference, which will bring us one step closer to putting a Tax Reform bill on the president's desk.  For more quick updates about my work in Washington, please sign-up to receive my e-newsletter.
Are you interested in learning more about the current tax reform bill? Add your name to the list for Congressman Budd’s next tele-town hall.

It’s no secret that much of the terror funding and civil unrest in the Middle East can be traced directly back to Iran.  I'm calling for more oversight and transparency over Iran’s business with the U.S.

It’s not uncommon these days to see Iranian fingerprints all over the instability and unrest that plagues the Middle East. In order to shed light on Iranian terror activities and let the Iranian people know how their leaders actually operate, we must expose the financial assets of the senior Iranian officials involved in corruption and illicit finance.   Today, the House passed the H.R. 1638, the Iranian Leadership Asset Transparency Act. This bill that aims to take the necessary steps toward disrupting the Iranian terror network.
I had a great time discussing how the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act will provide a tax cut for the middle class and provide relief to working families during my Telephone Town Hall earlier this week.

Today, the House passed the Strengthening Oversight of Iran’s Access to Finance Act (H.R. 4324), a bill which I cosponsored. This bill would increase congressional oversight on commercial aircraft sales to Iran. Since we’ve lifted sanctions on Iran under the Iran Nuclear Agreement, including government controlled entities like Iran Air, we’ve opened ourselves up to potentially financing Iran’s destabilizing activity in the region. We need more oversight on these commercial aircraft sales.   This bill is necessary because even this year, we’ve seen Iran Air continue to fly well- known weapon resupply routes to Pro-Assad controlled areas of Syria. Iran, the world’s largest state sponsor of terrorism, will always continue to find new and creative ways to bypass sanctions to fund their worldwide terror network. We must stay on constant alert, and this bill helps us do just that.

For too many years, Congress has promised and failed to close loopholes and fend off special interest groups, until now. Today’s vote on the tax bill conference report moves us one step closer to delivering hard working American families the tax relief we promised.   I am proud to have supported this legislation, which puts more money in the pockets of American families, creates more American jobs and makes our businesses competitive in the global economy. I look forward to seeing this historic tax reform bill on the president’s desk before Christmas.

At the start of 2017, Congress promised that it would provide relief to hardworking American families. Today, we delivered on this promise and sent the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act to President Trump’s desk. This historic bill will lower rates, double the standard deduction, and bring jobs back to America. I am proud to have been a part of ensuring that families in North Carolina and across the country will be able to keep more of their money.

The 2nd Amendment helps protect our other liberties as Americans, and I believe that it should be preserved. This week, I sent a letter to Republican leadership expressing my opposition to bringing the Fix NICs act up for a vote without attaching national concealed carry reciprocity. This letter makes a strong statement -- gun laws will not be expanded in the House without protecting the national concealed carry rights of law-abiding gun owners.
